main.java.com.github.dhyanamvaidya.binaryTree

Class BinaryTree<V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • main.java.com.github.dhyanamvaidya.binaryTree.BinaryTree<V>
  • Type Parameters:
    V - The type of values held in the Tree

    public class BinaryTree<V>
extends java.lang.Object
    Binary Tree is a node-based binary tree data structure which has the following properties: -- Each node can contain left and right child tree nodes -- Both the left and right subtrees must also be binary trees -- It can be used (extended) as a Binary Search Tree where the left child of a node is lesser in value than the root and right child is greater in value than the root Each object in the BinaryTree class represents a single node; however, nodes are linked together, so that any node may be considered as the "root" of a complete tree
    Version:
    26 September 2014
    Author:
    Dhyanam Vaidya

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BinaryTree(V value)
      Creates a BinaryTree node with the given value
      BinaryTree(V value, BinaryTree<V> leftChild, BinaryTree<V> rightChild)
      Creates a BinaryTree node and sets its plus its left and right child values with the given values

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void clear()
      Removes all of the mappings from this BinaryTree and resets the node with null values
      boolean contains(BinaryTree<V> node)
      Returns true if this BinaryTree contains the given node (not an equal node).
      boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
      Returns true if (1) given object is a BinaryTree, and (2) the value field of the two BinaryTrees are equal, and (3) each child of one BinaryTree equals the corresponding child of the other BinaryTree
      int getHeight()
      Returns the height of the BinaryTree on which this method is called For a tree with just one node, the root node, the height is defined to be 0, if there are 2 levels of nodes the height is 1 and so on A null tree (no nodes except the null node) is defined to have a height of negative 1 Height of a tree is the depth of farthest most leaf node from the root (max depth)
      BinaryTree<V> getKthLargestNode(int k)
      Returns the Kth Largest element present in the BinaryTree rooted at this node or NULL if not present This method will give accurate results only if the BinaryTree on which this method is called is a BinarySearchTree
      BinaryTree<V> getKthSmallestNode(int k)
      Returns the Kth Smallest element present in the BinaryTree rooted at this node or NULL if not present This method will give accurate results only if the BinaryTree on which this method is called is a BinarySearchTree
      java.util.LinkedList<BinaryTree<V>> getLeaves()
      Returns the LinkedList containing only the leaves of this BinaryTree on which this method is called
      BinaryTree<V> getLeftChild()
      Gets the value of the left child of this BinaryTree node
      int getNumberOfChildren()
      Returns the number of (immediate) children of this node
      BinaryTree<V> getRightChild()
      Gets the value of the right child of this BinaryTree node
      V getValue()
      Gets the value in this node of the BinaryTree
      int hashCode()
      Returns the hash code value for this BinaryTree.
      void inOrderTraversal()
      Prints the nodes of this BinaryTree in an inOrder traversal to the console
      boolean isBalanced()
      Returns true if difference between heights of its left subtrees and right subtrees is not more than 1 and left and right subtrees are balanced, otherwise return false.
      boolean isLeaf()
      Returns true if this node has no children.
      boolean isSymmetric()
      Returns true if the left subtree of this node is the same as its right subtree in values and shape
      static BinaryTree<java.lang.String> parse(java.lang.String treeDescription)
      Translates a String description of a tree into a Tree object.
      void postOrderTraversal()
      Prints the nodes of this BinaryTree in a postOrder traversal to the console
      void preOrderTraversal()
      Prints the nodes of this BinaryTree in a preOrder traversal to the console
      void print()
      Prints a multi-line version of the tree For example, for the Tree: one / \ / \ two three /\ / \ four five /\ / \ six seven print method will output the below tree one | two | three | | four | | | six | | | seven | | five
      BinaryTree<V> removeLeftChild()
      Removes and returns the left child of this BinaryTree (as a complete subtree), or throws a NoSuchElementException if the left child is not present
      BinaryTree<V> removeRightChild()
      Removes and returns the right child of this BinaryTree (as a complete subtree), or throws a NoSuchElementException if the left child is not present
      void setLeftChild(BinaryTree<V> leftChild)
      Sets the node supplied as the left child of this BinaryTree node
      void setRightChild(BinaryTree<V> rightChild)
      Sets the node supplied as the right child of this BinaryTree node
      void setValue(V value)
      Sets the value in this node of the BinaryTree
      int size()
      Returns the number of nodes including the root in the Binary Tree rooted at this node
      java.lang.String toString()
      Returns a String representing this Tree.

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a String representing this Tree. The returned String is in the same format as the parse method expects as input. For example, for the Tree: one / \ / \ two three /\ / \ four five /\ / \ six seven
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        toString method will return the below String, "one(two three(four(six seven) five))"
        See Also:
        Object.toString()

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Returns the hash code value for this BinaryTree. The hash code of a BinaryTree is defined to be the sum of the hash codes of root and its left child and its right child. This ensures that node1.equals(node2) implies that node1.hashCode()==node2.hashCode() for any two nodes node1 and node2 of type BinaryTree as required by the general contract of Object.hashCode().
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class java.lang.Object

      • parse

        public static BinaryTree<java.lang.String> parse(java.lang.String treeDescription)
        Translates a String description of a tree into a Tree object. The treeDescription has the form value(child child), where a value is any sequence of characters not containing parentheses or whitespace, and each child is either just a (String) value or is another treeDescription. Whitespace is used to separate values. For example, the String "one(two three(four(six seven) five))" becomes the Tree: one / \ / \ two three /\ / \ four five /\ / \ six seven
        Parameters:
        treeDescription - The String to be parsed
        Returns:
        The resultant Tree<String<

        public boolean isBalanced()
        Returns true if difference between heights of its left subtrees and right subtrees is not more than 1 and left and right subtrees are balanced, otherwise return false.
        Returns:
        true if the BinaryTree is balanced

      • getHeight

        public int getHeight()
        Returns the height of the BinaryTree on which this method is called For a tree with just one node, the root node, the height is defined to be 0, if there are 2 levels of nodes the height is 1 and so on A null tree (no nodes except the null node) is defined to have a height of negative 1 Height of a tree is the depth of farthest most leaf node from the root (max depth)
        Returns:
        The height of this BinaryTree
